description.text:
3D printer using coreXY type concept. Added a box to enclose the printer.

Auto bed leveling is a function that makes printing so easy, no more hand tuning with these screws, even if they are left in this design for the fans with manual leveling (will there be anybody?).

The spool is integrated into the printer's body so you don't need to find a place for a separated spool. And you can move the printer around easily without needing to move the spool as well.

Printed parts optimized for less material usage and great tolerance of dimension error.

2020 aluminium profiles (square tube is used for prototype 1 & 2)
8mm harden steel shaft + LM8UU linear bearings
atmega2560 + ramps board
Nema17 4401 motors
bowden extruder

//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
Je suis à Paris, et j'ai réalisé plusieurs prototype. Si vous voulez une imprimante SO-1 assemblée et prêt à utiliser, n'hésitez pas à me contacter.

description.text: "A sputtering torch revealed the black-clad scalers, and the hue was sounded forthwith." --Qie Zi, The Art of Seej The plural of block is bloxen. The singular of bloxen is bloxen. This is an interlocking castle block. It's the fundamental defensive model for playing Seej. Rules for Seej can be found at http://www.s33j.net

Construction is snap-together. LED and battery not included! Insert a LED into the socket. Bend the leads of the LED into the grooves on the side of the socket. Put a battery into the socket's mortise. If the LED doesn't light up, flip the battery around. Slide the socket into the bloxen and snap it into place. The two tenons on the bloxen should fit into the battery mortise, pushing the battery up and helping secure the socket to the bloxen. Cap the LED with the torch diffuser. This uses a DL1025 or equivalent battery. Amazon sells them for about two bucks: http://amzn.to/LkNAx8 This bloxen looks really cool with a candle flicker LED inside: http://youtu.be/5xuSnIKwyZ4 The sconce bloxen and socket also have bores cut through them in case you want to drive the LED with an Arduino or a different power source. Two 22 gauge hookup wires should just fit.

description.text:
Simple two piece quad frame.
The frame is 170mm and uses 4" props. (in my case 4045 4-blades)

I wanted a frame for some old 1806 motors and other disused parts.
But any motors that can swing a 4" prop and matching ESC and FC will do.

The height 8 standoffs needs to be adapted to match the height of the PDB and any components below it.

I used the following parts.
DYS BE1806
https://www.banggood.com/DYS-BE1806-2300KV-Brushless-Motor-Black-Edition-for-Multicopters-p-946416.html
Naze32 Rev5
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/afroflight-naze32-acro-funfly-controller.html
4045 props
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/dalprop-q4045-bull-nose-4-blade-propellers-cw-ccw-set-green-2-pairs.html
ESC
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/dys-blheli-16a-mini-esc-with-soldering-pin-option-2-4s.html
PDB
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/super-mini-power-distribution-board-w-twin-bec-5v-12v-for-cc3d-revo-flight-controllers.html
Micro Camera and VTX
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/q25-mini-vtx-and-camera.html

You will need a XT60 connector, 12* M3 10mm bolts, 4 longer M3 bolts with nuts for mounting the PDB and FC and mounting hardware for your motors.

The receiver is and old 6 channel FlySky that had its plastic cover removed
But any 4+ channel receiver will do.

I am using cleanflight with stock PIDs
On a 3s 1300mAh LiPo it´s not super fast and i don´t think my setup will handle 4s

The pictures are from a earlier version.

After some testing and a number of quite hard caches (on grass) i can confirm that the frame can take some serious abuse!

Printed with PLA and 40% infill.

title: Microscope Slide Storage styled on Sir Sherrington's Histology Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Sir Charles Scott Sherrington (27 November 1857 – 4 March 1952) was an English neurophysiologist, histologist, bacteriologist, and a pathologist, Nobel laureate and president of the Royal Society in the early 1920s. He received the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with Edgar Adrian, 1st Baron Adrian, in 1932 for their work on the functions of neurons.

This 3D model is a close representation of Sherrington's Histology Box that was recovered in circa 2010. The model is meant for storage of 10 microscopy slides as compared to the original which is a whole microbiology closet. The individual slide compartments have a pit arrangement which is designed for a regular microscopy slide (75 x 25 mm) wherein the slide can sit inside. The slide pit also has a handle to allow it to be slid in and out of the box's compartment with ease.

The model has been created with a view of 'fancy storage' for permanent microscopy slides. It gives a vintage touch to the regular item and I am sure it would look fantastic on a Teacher's desktop.

This Thing is a work in progress for now as I look forward to add compartments for slides of different dimensions.

If you ever print one, please remember to post your print in the 'I Made One' section.

Thank you!

Please Note:
The First model in the 3D preview is NOT a print-in-place model. It is only for the purpose of representation. Print the Base and the slide compartments separately.

description.text:
This is a small air filter, which is powered by a 45x10mm DC fan. The filter mainly consists of the fan and four 3D printable parts. They are called intake tunnel, lid, fan entry mount and fan exit.

The air filter is designed to work as follows:

  1. When the fan is ON and the filter is capped with the lid, air should be sucked into the filter through the air tunnels.
  2. The air should flow down to a small volume where active carbon is stored there.
  3. The filtered air should flow through the grid underlain and enter the fan.
  4. Finally, the air should be propelled and blown out through the nozzle.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

1. Sandwich the fan between fan entry and fan exit

Make sure the fan direction is correct !
Air should blow towards the exit part.
Use two M3 x 12 screws to fasten the block.

2. Attach the air tunnels to the main block

Use little glue if necessary.

3. Fill in active carbon

Fill in active carbon packs or granules above the grid of the fan.

4. Cover the lid

Use glue or tape to fix the assembly if necessary.
Paul Kenett's modified design for single cells.

title: Nozzle Fan 60mm Prusa i3 MK2S Upgrade

description.text:
Hello fellow Prusa i3 Mk2s maker

After discovering the good looking 60mm Fan Part from Christian Auth, I was exited to print it. Just to see that the STLs are missing. So i sat down and made my own version of it. Now you can print it with any material you print with and not just with the one who is in the gcode files :-)

New Part

The goal of the new part was to be basic, streamlined, functional and not too much space consuming.

This was partly achieved by using the 1.5cm the Prusa fan is using. However due to the Extruder Motor ontop this was only possible to an extent.

Please post your makes :-)

Assembly

Remove old fan from the Extruder cover and leave the "HOT" piece in place it is used by this part.

You can use the guide on the left side to position it correctly. It is not aligned with the Extruder motor.

Buy this fan: http://noctua.at/de/products/fan/nf-a6x25-flx/specification

Solder the wires together, or crimp them....

And screw fan onto mount .-)

History:

-v1: Initial release
-v2: made the nut hole fit
-v3: made the fan hole a bit bigger

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Use "Supports only on build plate" for best results.

Remove Supports

Remove supports with pliers and tweezers. Polish part with sand paper for good air flow.

Support should be easily to remove.
ThinkerCAD

title: Versatile Anet A8 Tool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NEW: Fixed the little gap in some models' screwdriver base. Thanks to floppyslap for finding that issue and to DJaw for the photo! My black filament doesn't photograph well...

Some of the other tool holders I saw looked like they would interfere with my frame braces, would be annoying to install, or didn't hold the tools I wanted. This one solves those issues. It's really easy to install: it clips on the inside of the vertical frame and is secured using either the top screw of the power supply or the hole above the circuit board. Every tool is easily removed--the hex wrenches can be popped in or out or dropped into place.

It holds 4 hex wrenches, the small screwdriver, spanner, and a few other tools of your choice (snippers, needlenose pliers, larger screwdriver, file, USB drive, etc)... you can fit both snipper handles into the two circular openings if you want or put a tool into each.

If you want to put this on the left frame just mirror it before printing, then use a nut and m3 bolt in the hole above the circuit board.

description.text:
I've created this C-Clamp (or G-Clamp if you like to call it this way) because of three reasons.

1) For my upcoming enclosure build I'll need some clamps to hold parts together.
2) To train my Fusion 360 skills
3) I've never printed threads on my (new) 3D printer. So it was a good way to tests what threats are easy to print an working reasonable well.

As usual I've attached the Fusion 360 file to make adjustments easier for you. You will also find a factory file with the settings from my Prusa MKS2 and PLA from Das Filament.

During the design phase I used this https://goo.gl/YcnZ7b to test various threads, diameter, offset etc. combination to find a good working and printable thread. Perhaps it's a good idea to print this first to test if the combination is suitable for your printer, too. Also it migth a good starting point for your own thread tests.

Side note: I'm new to 3D printing and I've to learn everything. I believe that making things on your own from the very first step is harder but finally you will get things done. Because of that I try not to download lot of things but create them from scratch. Even if they already exists. By sharing those things I hope to get feedback that I can improve my skills. So don't be angry if I upload things which already exists here.

Update 2017/09/04: Link to thread test (https://goo.gl/YcnZ7b) added
Update 2017/08/09: You're preferring screw clamps? Try this (https://goo.gl/LvzV1z).
Update 2017/08/02: Based on the feedback from @wavapps I've added to additional versions of the C-Clamp

C-Clamp 01 (red"C"): Unchanged
C-Clamp 02 (yellow "C"): Like @waveapps I wasn't sure about the retainers of the shoe. Now they are about 3 times thicker. I haven't printed them yet because my printer is busy, but unless the gaps didn't change everything should still work. @wavapps reported a slight bending on the lower part of the clamp so I've added a cut out to the lower part of the "C" with half of the depth of the original cut outs. I haven't done this initially because I was afraid of to thin walls or screws but this might be a good compromise.
C-Clamp 03 (blue "C"):Thicker retainers like for clamp 02 (but all the shoes are interchangeable) and a full depth cut out on the lower part of the "C" Because of the cut out the depth is now slightly bigger.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

For my first (and currently only) print I've used 8 shells, top and bottom layers. Perhaps to much. I don't know.

You might want to add some support below the cut outs of the "C" if you print it lying on the bed.

description.text:
This slick Pi Zero case has razor sharp tolerances that can only come from numerous iterations. Less than 6mm thick. Walls are 1.6mm for ideal printing with a 0.4mm nozzle. It snaps together snugly, but adding some pan-head screws will provide standoffs to allow air flow over the bottom vents.

UPDATE: v07c Added cutout for MicroSD and various other slight improvements.

UPDATE: v08 Added for Pi Zero W compatibility.

UPDATE: v09b Added with 2x20 right-angle headers for easy GPIO connection. Solder 2x20 Right angle header inserted with bottom of connector flush with bottom of board (farther in than typical). After soldering, trim the pins with a flush cutter to prevent them extending through the bottom opening. You can now build/proto with minimal thickness added.

title: TBS RaceTracker Gate Interface Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The TBS RaceTracker LED Gate Interface transforms any any WS2812B RGB LED strip into a "Smart Gate". When connected to your TBS RaceTracker it will dynamically color the LED gates according to the TBS frequency/color scheme, and it will show other things like race start/stop, gate lock/unlock, fastest lap, etc. Supports multiple pilots for a single Race Tracker as well using the latest firmware upgrade!
The best use-case for this is to have a start/finish gate that dyanmically shows spectators the above race parameters without having to sift through "standings tables". With a few of these hooked to Race Trackers you could even animate your entire course! Since it works with pretty much every LED strip out of the box, the only limit is your imagination!

author: lhancock

description.text:
Maria Fjodorovna Barjatinskaja (1793-1858) Statue in marble, after the original model from 1818 (A171). Thorvaldsen Museum (Copenhagen, Denmark). Made with Memento Beta (now ReMake) from AutoDesk.

The Russian Princess Maria Barjatinskaja came to Rome in 1818 with her husband. At his wish, she was modelled by Thorvaldsen. The marble sculpture was created in 1821-25, but was never delivered. After the Princess’s death, her family demanded to have the statue handed over, but instead accepted a copy made by Thorvaldsen’s most important Danish apprentice, the sculptor H. W. Bissen. Today the sculpture is in the Pushkin Museum in Moscow.

For more updates, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

remixed_from.title: ECLIPSE 3D Printable ‘USA and STATE’ PINHOLE PROJECTORS

description.text:
The August 21, 2017 eclipse will be observable across America. While those in the path of totality will see a TOTAL solar eclipse, everyone will be treated to a PARTIAL eclipse! Where will you be? Why not celebrate the eclipse by making your own 3D Printed Pinhole Projector in the shape of the USA and/or of each US State? See all of NASA's 3D Printable Pinhole Projectors.

Ask a friend to take a picture of your shadow while holding your state’s pinhole projector. The resulting image will be a once in a lifetime picture of your shadow, the shadow of your selected state and a projected image of the partial eclipse marking your location!
Edit this model on Tinkercad.

Upper basket bracket replacement for Omega ODW507TXB dishwasher. Original bracket degraded and failed (and was a nasty fibreglass reinforced molding too, how is that food safe?). Replacement bracket is for drawer in up position only, as we have never used the upper basket in the low position (thats why it doesn't look much like the original). Just clips in and is very strong. Drawing has been changed to include improvements to strength, necessary due to failure of the original design (it was too flexible, dishwasher too hot).

description.text:

Container is 73x50mm and 40mm height and fits nicely in my tool box (see pictures).

author: makerslabcz

description.text:
A modified RepRapPro Huxley extruder. Changes made include:
  • - Herringbone Gear set
  • - Thicker section on M6 block
  • - 'Spacers' added to M6 block so it sits nicely on the threaded rod
  • - Longer lever/handle added to idler
  • - Long M3 threaded rods instead of set screws
  • - Wing Nuts
  • - Easier access to change filament or clean hobbed bolt

Herringbone Gear Set
The hole for the captive screw on the small gear has been moved using an offest parameter in the Gregs_Accessible_Wade_Herringbone_Gears_for_Huxley_Extruder.scad file. It was too close to the shaft hole. Print out the gear set at the highest quality you can manage. I used a layer height of 0.2mm. The herringbone teeth pattern is not forgiving and accuracy is important if they are to mesh correctly. After printing out the gears spend time using a file, sharp craft knife or sandpaper (or all three) to carefully clean up each tooth of the gears. The angle of the teeth make this a difficult process but it's very important otherwise your gears will bind. You can use the gear_spacer_jig to set the stepper motor shaft at the correct distance from the hobbed bolt. Slide it over the motor shaft and hobbed bolt before tightening the stepper motor screws. Make sure it sits squarely and then tighten the screws securing the stepper motor. Remove the jig. Fitting the gears is tricky as they will not slide past each other. Hold the gears togehter with their teeth meshed and slide them onto the shafts. Make sure they are meshed correctly. Once the gears are fitted spend time turning them and checking for any binding. Use your file/knife/sandpaper to adjust each tooth until they turn smoothly. M6 block and Idler lever/handle
Print out the M6 block and Idler lever/handle. Fit the Idler to the M6 block using the pivot screw and check how far it opens remove the idler to adjust it. I used sandpaper/file to carefully round the ends of the idler. I also spent some time removing material around the area where the Idler pivots on the M6 block to increase the clearance. A large diameter drill bit is useful. Hold it in the 'corners' of the M6 block and turn it by hand to file away material. I also filed away a lot of the bridge section that spans the gap the bearing sit in. This allows the lever/handle to open further - be careful not to remove too much of the span as this may over weaken it. Spring compression rods
I replaced the M3 x 45mm screws with long sections of M3 threaded rod. I glued the nuts into the recesses as I was fed up with them falling out each time I adjusted the spring compression. If your'e going to glue them then do so with the rod already screwed into them to make sure they are correctly aligned. I used M3 wing nuts to make adjustments easier without the need for tools. To allow the lever/handle to open more fully I used a drill bit at an angle to elongage the holes in the idler that the M3 rods go through. Thicker Tongue
The original tongue that holds the Bowden tube end in the M6 block was quite loose and allowed the end to go in and out as the extruder retracted. I reduced this by changing the thickness of the tongue prongs. The tongue_thicker_prongs.scad file now has a parameter to allow you set the dimension of the prongs. After printing out the tongue I then incrementally filed away material to the point that it gave a very snug and fit - the brass Bowden tube end now doesn't move at all.

Great test idea, thank you Vicky.
Hope you don't mind me remixing.
When I sliced the original in S3D, I noticed that some of the numbers would not be printed as part of the main body. I'm not criticising the original design at all. It was a great excuse to practice Fusion 360 :-) ... Like I ever need an excuse lol.
So, off I went and redesigned the whole thing, mostly guessing the sizes (apart from the obvious ones, of course) and it turned out huge lol
Right, back to the beginning then, well, not exactly. Ain't parametric modelling great lol.

Sure, I could have imported the mesh, but I wanted to practice.

title: Repkord 1/2 lb Spool Container Tool Caddy

description.text:
Repkord 1/2 lb spool caddy. I've made a few for tools and for painting.

After printing the drawer insert it into the repkord spool and mark where the top hinge will align. (pretty close to the edge) Then remove it and drill the hole through the top and bottom. Included is a drawer hinge to fit into the bottom of the drawer. Clean out the bottom hold and insert the hinge. (glue if you like, or drop and lose it 2 times like I did... ) Then spread the spool slightly and insert the drawer, repeat for each drawer. You can use the drawer slots as spacers if you want.

author: dharjung

title: Transmission Model: Shifter & Differential
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to learn more about manual transmissions so I designed this simple hand-cranked version that snaps together and uses two ball bearings (I designed a frame with no bearings but I haven't printed it yet... the photos show a prototype with 4 bearings which was just too much). It has a differential gear and manual shifter with 1st-Neutral-2nd gear configuration. All the important parts of a car transmission are included except the clutch... In a way, your crank hand represents throttle and the clutch (hand off = clutch in).
.
.
Printing:
I printed this in 3 sections according to their print needs: two require support while the other does not, and two of the three should be printed solid or with high fill. I included a frame that uses ball bearings and one that doesn't... use whichever one you'd like. Each file has its requirements in the file name.
.
.
Assembly:

  1. Look closely at the gears with outside teeth--I will describe them by the shape in their center... there are 2 "plugs", 2 "squares", 4 "circles", 1 "1-flat", and 3 "2-flat" gears. Notice that the two thicker "circle" gears are really two gears joined together: one of these has triangular 'pointed' teeth. The two tiny "circle" gears also have pointed teeth.
    .
  2. Orient the frame so it looks like a T (that's what I will call it from now on). From the top of the T, put the axle with the gear on it through the hole on the right-hand side of the middle of the frame. Onto this axle put (in this order):
    • Larger "circle" double gear, pointed teeth toward you
    • Thin "circle" gear, pointed teeth toward you
    • Thicker "2-flat" gear... then find the gear (selector) with INSIDE teeth. Slide it over this gear
    • Thin "circle" gear, pointed teeth away from you
    • Smaller "circle" double gear, pointed teeth away from you
    • Small spacer disk
      .
  3. Make sure the "2-flat" gear locks into position (you will need to rotate it until it fits) as you push the axle through the hole in the bottom-right of the T.
    .
  4. From the bottom of the T, put the other long axle through the left hole in the T. Onto this axle, put (in this order):
    • Largest "2-flat" gear
    • Smallest "2-flat" gear
      .
  5. Keep the larger "2-flat" gear pressed against the bottom of the T as you push the axle through the hole in the center of the T. Each gear should mesh nicely with the corresponding gear on the other axle. Assemble the crank and attach it on the square end of this axle.
    .
  6. Find the two "shifter" pieces--one has 1-N-2 printed on it. Put these above and below the selector (inside-teeth gear) and snap them together. You can shift by sliding this forward and backward.
    .
  7. The 2 remaining axles have non-centered spacer rings. (If you're using 20 mm ball bearings, put the shorter ends into the bearings now.) Notice that one axle has a flat surface. Put the large "1-flat" gear on this axle so that the narrowest part of the teeth is away from the short end of the axle. This axle goes on the right... it may be difficult to put this gear into place so be careful. From the middle of the T, put the short end of each axle (including bearings, if you are using them) through the frame.
    .
  8. The remaining parts make up the differential in the middle of the T. Put the big ring on the left axle, with the cut-away part to the right. Then place the part that looks like a green lantern symbol (or TIE fighter) onto the left axle. Push the two "square" gears on the inside ends of each axle.
    .
  9. Put the "plug" gears in the holes of each curved 'arm' so that the gear is on the concave side. Secure these arms onto the 'green lantern/TIE fighter' piece then slide the ring over the pieces to secure the arms in place.
    .
  10. Have fun as you crank, shift, and grind your gears!

author: Aerofun-Fpv

description.text:
Order extra 24v fan to connect in parallel to the factory fan. Mount using m3 bolts/nuts.
I used left-over space of thread used for bearing in the carriage for mounting support rod. Make sure you have space and your bolt is not touching the small one that is inside he shaft to hold the bearing.
Use abs or pet/g to print the parts.

After some prints i still got too much heath from the cartridge in the back. So i took a piece of aluminum of about 5x7 cm and bended it to fit under cartridge. It needs a big hole at right place for the nozzle ofcourse. Mount with twosided tape. See last two pictures i added.

Next version of the duct will be closed with only a gap for the nozzle. On that you can stick a layer of aluminum foil and capton tape.

comments.text: Looks great! My question is though, where do you plug the second fan in to? Do you need a special adapter or something? As far as I can see, there isn't a place to plug an extra fan in for me.
comments.author: Thunder025

comments.text:
Hi Thunder025,
Cut the wires at a good size and solder in parallel (red to red, black to black). Then you will have 1 connector left to put in original place.
I will add a photo. Exact length of wires depends on used fans and how you mount them.
Use crimp sock to prevent shortcutting power.
comments.author: Thunder025

comments.text: I love this design! Have you noticed any adverse effects from the extra fan on your power supply?
comments.author: MalusLupus13

comments.text:
Hi MalusLupus13, thanks.
As far as i know the powersupply is overrated and the current these fans use is low.
I just changed the nozzle with full metal hot-end and made print with PETG on high temp. Extruder 265c, Printbed 65c and fanspeed 40%.
No problem.

title: Easy Print Voronoi Tealight Candle Holder

description.text:
Note: This project was not intended to be used with a real tealight - plastic and fire does not mix well so I strongly recommend you go and get an LED tealight with a flickering effect. They are super cheap to buy.

I have been meaning to have a go at my own Voronoi style tea light holder for some time. I am pretty happy with it! And once I got my head around how to go about creating it I only spent an hour on this project.

I made a few tweaks to the design to ensure that it prints well (voronoi can be a nightmare on my budget 3D printer). But here are some tips:

The design prints without supports, infill shouldn't matter but I used 100% as there wasn't much in it. The lower you set the layer height the better the print will be. I had mine at .2 and it printed perfectly. I also recommend slow printing speeds of around 30mm/s.

As the title suggests it should be a nice easy print but if you have any questions just ask.

Printer:

Colido DIY 3D Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I probably would not exceed 30mm/s print speed due to the delicate voronoi walls but if you do please let me know how it turns out.
I designed the tea light holder within Fusion 360. I then took the design over to Autodesk's Meshmixer software to convert the walls into a Voronoi pattern.

author: Luke3DP

title: Alien Architects: Monument Counters
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
KICKSTARTER ALERT- Hey, everyone. We've just launched a kickstarter campaign for our friend Jeff Bowers' competitive card game, Alien Architects!

"There are exceptional monuments, buildings, and statues on Earth that have left archaeologists wondering for millennia about their origins and construction. The Great Pyramids of Egypt, the Moai of Easter Island, Stonehenge of England, the Ball of Twine of Kansas; could early civilizations of humans have designed and built these with limited technology and knowledge? Or is it possible (even probable) that we, on this planet, have been receiving help from more advanced cultures from other worlds? In Alien Architects you take on the role of an extraterrestrial who has traveled across the galaxy to compete with other aliens to build monuments on earth throughout human history. Collect or steal resources, blueprints, and technology in order to prove that you are the greatest builder in the universe. And why not have some fun with the humans while you’re here?"

These monument icons (while a fun addition) aren't necessary to play the game, but we figured we should make them anyway. Printed sets of these may be included as rewards for the "Invader" pledge level, but if you have access to a 3D printer you can download them here and print them yourself.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text:
FIRST: if your issue is just centering prints using Cura and your printer is set as a 'Prusa i3' make sure you go to Settings > Printers > Manage Printers > Machine Settings and change your dimensions to 220 x 220 x 240. If that solves your problems feel free to like this thing anyway ;D

My Anet A8 x-stop switch couldn't be attached with the screws provided... I drilled new holes but didn't like the offset that caused. This quick print helps fix both problems. Pop this on the top X rail and slide it over the original plastic frame. With an m3*12 bolt and m3 nut you can now move that x-stop switch and lock it where you like it... even if it's just where it was originally supposed to go.

Also, instead of using the top clip you could use a tiny bit of glue or adhesive putty to hold the switch in place.

This thing is a clip to fasten a 950mAh Turnigy nano-tech battery to the Zerotech Dobby.

As well as the battery a JST connector soldered to a couple of 2.8mm female spade terminals is all that is required. The spade terminals fit neatly and tightly between the outer battery connectors on the Dobby (make sure that the positive is on the left!). The battery then fits perfectly into the battery bay. Mount the 3D printed battery clip so that it traps both the balance and discharge leads between clip and battery so that they can't get snagged by the propellers.

Using this system means that both cheap lipo batteries and the Zerotech Dobby batteries can be used inter-changeably.

comments.text: Hi Turnigy NanoTech batteries is 2S Lipo batteries 7.4V instead Dobby batteries is 2S Lipo HV 7,6V batteries. How is Dobby flight with standard Lipp instead LipoHV?
comments.author: twinjet75

comments.text: The Dobby battery is Li-ion not Lipo and so there is a small warning triangle over the battery icon in do.fun.  However, although I've only done one proper test, it would seem that the nanotech battery gives a slightly longer flight time, probably about 30 seconds or so.  Having said that, I'm sticking with the original Dobby batteries because they are easier to use.
comments.author: twinjet75

comments.text: Can you comment whether your flight time is any better with a non-Zerotech battery? Also I am curious if the battery is capacity and remaining is read correctly. I bought some actually Dobby spare batteries and quickly realized that they are some how not compatible. They charge for an appropriate amount of time, the charge indicator lights on the batteries show full but when used the app shows the battery remaining percent dropping like instantly but then the battery still thinks it is full.
comments.author: m00nlightt3ch

comments.text: Don't worry about the Dobby battery dropping like a stone, it is notorious for that but you should still get a good 5 minutes out of it.

description.text:
A little late for this new year, but it can be a "Farewell 2017" ornament in December and of course it's reusable every twelve years!
I made it for a young friend nicknamed "Rooster" because she was born in the last year of the rooster.
Many thanks to Selva 3D, a great free website.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

medium

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printed in white PLA to show the wood grain effect on the surface of the contoured half egg, and so it is semi-translucent for back-lighting.

Optional decoration

Apply nail polish to the surfaces of the raised rooster image to add any color suits your rooster's fancy. I have found nail polish to be the best "paint" for PLA because it's an enamel and fills the grain well.

I used the free website Selva 3D to raise the dark parts of a 2D image of a Maori rooster tatoo.
Next I imported it to TinkerCad & placed it atop a flattened TinkerCad egg cut in half to make a plaque.
Then I contoured the flat raised rooster with a "bowl hole" as shown in the attached PDF tutorials.

title: Tolerance Test - Individual and with special tool

description.text:
This are 5 individual tolerances test, from 0,10mm to 0,50mm
I believe printing them individually will make things faster and allow us to play with more configs on how to print them.
Can't suggest printing settings, as this is the fun of this objects, to print them trying different ones.
Please have fun with them and remember to post photos and share your thoughts.
PS: Print the "Tool" only in case you want some extra assistant to help unlock the pieces if they don't come out perfect.
PS2: I will have versions with "Fillets" on the borders and also will be adding the in between numbers like 0,15 or 0,25 soon.

comments.text: Great idea, this safes so much fillament and time compared to other tolerance tests.

title: Linear Advance for Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
This is for the firmware update that enables Linear Advance.
Link for download: http://www.prusamk2.com/linear-advance-prusa-mk2/

Summary:
Source: Marlin

Under default conditions, extruder axis movement is treated in the same way as the XYZ linear axes. The extruder motor moves in linear proportion to all the other motors, maintaining exactly the same acceleration profile and start/stop points. But an extruder isn’t a linear system, so this approach leads, most obviously, to extra material being extruded at the end of each linear movement.

Take the common test-cube as an example. Even with the best tuning the corners are usually not sharp, but bleed out. The top solid infill displays roughness where the print direction changes on perimeters. These problems are minor or even imperceptible at low printing speeds, but they become more noticeable and problematic as print speeds increase.

Tuning the flow can help, but this may lead to under-extrusion when starting new lines. Some slicers include an option to end extrusion early in each move, but this adds more complexity to the G-code and has to be re-tuned for different temperatures and materials.

Since the root cause is pressure, LIN_ADVANCE de-couples extrusion from the other axes to produce the correct pressure inside the nozzle, adapting to the printing speed. Once Linear Advance is properly tuned, bleeding edges and rough solid infill should be nearly eliminated.

Again...
Link for download: http://www.prusamk2.com/linear-advance-prusa-mk2/

description.text:
So there I was minding my own business when a viewer called me out on the dodgy looks of my caliper holder (in a nice way as he was right :-) on the pegboard and said I should remix his (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1800659) for a better look so I took up the challenge and sharing the results with you guys! Also here is a similar version caliper (http://amzn.to/2w2X4rt) for less than 10 bucks if your interested!

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! author: mismas

description.text:
I was thinking about making larger things with a makerbot, but given the available print area that means breaking it down into parts.
So I had the idea to break larger objects down into multiple "modular" components for assembly.
A wine rack seemed to make sense because its real object, has to hold weight, is relatively simple in form and because its allows expression of the modular nature by adding to it when you need to.
This is just an experiment I don't know if the "pin" mechanism I've used to hold it together will be strong enough, or if the units will tolerate bearing weight.
If anyone prints out even a single unit please let me know how it works (I've got a few weeks to go before my bot turn up).

This design is untested. 3 STLs 3 part types
Base (2 per print)
Main (2 per print)
Pin (8 per print) SPK files included. ZIP of all files included for easy download. The image of the assembled rack should provide all the assembly guidance needed.

comments.text: I made one and i think the design is great. It supports the weight. The problem is the connector pins are to big and you end up having to literally hammer them into place, which of course stresses the component and will ultimately crack. Can you reduce the size of the connector pins?
comments.author: cs200222

title: Frameless Photo Stand (Parametric)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 6/19: v2.0 Now supports nearly thirty common coins for added weight!
This is a simple parametric frameless photo stand that uses (with its default values) only about 50-60mm of filament (about a penny or two) and holds up a photo for display without the use of a frame. It can be weighted with a coin by specifying one of nearly 30 built-in common coin types for USA, Canada, Australia, and Europe (e.g. US_25C for a quarter, and EU_50C for a euro 50c). If the coin you want to use isn't in the list, you can just specify its diameter and thickness instead.
It's very quick and easy to print, and makes a fantastic and useful sample print for demos. There are 15 parameters to define the shape and size.
In the photos, it's holding up a standard-sized 5x7 photo (127x178mm). You can easily change the parameters to make it wider, longer, thicker, a different angle, different tab distance, tab size, coin weight, etc.

1) Print. (The STLs are for the coinless version, and one that accepts a US quarter for added weight.) 2) Insert photo. You can put the middle tab in front (as pictured) or in back. In front it's less visible, but in back adds a nice curve to the photo and might allow it to stand up better with the default settings. I actually prefer it in back for landscape-oriented photos, and in the front for portrait-oriented photos. 3) Admire photo. You can just print the STL for a normal size photo. If you want full control over the design, change the parameters in the opensSCAD and re-render. The following parameters are available:
  • baseThickness: The thickness of the base
  • baseWidth: The width of the base
  • baseLength: The length of the base
  • baseSupportWidth: The minimal width of the support structure
  • coinSize: The coin to use, or [diameter,thickness]
  • coinClipPadding: The extra space built into to the coin clip
  • coinClipThickness: The thickness of the coin slot
  • coinSupportWidth: The width of the coin support surface
  • coinStopHeight: The width of the coin support surface
  • coinStopOverhang: The width of the coin support surface
  • tabThickness: The thickness of each vertical "tab"
  • tabHeight: The height of the vertical tabs.
  • tabRadius: The radius of the top corners of the tabs.
  • tabSeparation: How far apart the tabs are
  • tabAngle: The angle of the tabs (90 is vertical)
  • $fn: Quality of circles

author: Ginger13

description.text:
This is both parts of the side bracket for the Sony MDR-V6 headphones (likely compatible with other models in the MDR-V line), as I lost mine and realized that this bracket was one of the only replacement parts you could not buy. It is parametrized, so if you find the tolerances or exact size doesn't fit your specific headphones, just change the parameters a bit in the OpenSCAD file, just make sure the two pieces still fit together. OpenSCAD is a free, pretty lightweight software, so you can change the file pretty easily if needed.

Additionally, for the headphonebracket2.scad file, at the top of the code you can choose to have the printer print the curved edge or to have it print as a hard edge (but you will need to sand it down after in order for the headphones to still fold).

If you don't need to change anything, you just need the two .stl files, your own replacement screw, and you're good to go! If you only lost the bracket on one side of your headphone, it's a good idea to use half of each bracket on each side to help with the threading, otherwise you will likely need a threader.

Enjoy!

6.5mm screw hole.

Easy to print, rounded edges. Relatively thin (4-6mm) but strong enough for its intended usage. Has a full inch of height clearance when attached, which should be enough for most headbands to slide through. The length of the resting area is approximately 2 inches long and 1 inch wide.

Includes a slot for headphone wire management. Works well for when you have a long length cord and want to keep the wire from ending up in the wheels of your office chair, so you only pull the length you need through the hole and the rest will comfortably sit underneath the desk away from your wheels.

title: 606ZZ Two Bearing Fidget Spinner For 17mm Bearings

description.text: This a simple remix of the Fidget Spinner by Shinns and 606ZZ Batman Fidget Spinner For 17mm Bearings by me. I looked on Amazon for bearings and found some really cheap ones. They were about 10 for $3 for 606 ZZ bearings (rather than 3 for $10 for 608 ZZ bearings). Once I bought them I needed to soak them in gasoline to get the grease out, in order to let them spin freely. The bearings aren't the best, but for the price they are totally worth it. I have not yet been able to find many spinners for 17mm bearings, so I remixed my own. The caps are from the Batman spinner and the body is from the normal fidget spinner. If you have any comments, questions, suggestions, requests, or just want to say something, please leave a comment. https://youtu.be/QYOnn9uVVN4

title: 80's Car to Robot transformer with hubcap

description.text:
I loved the transformers in grade school. This is my design of the micro series that were similar to penny racers. They were released in the late 80's.

I've included the head as a single part for single extrusion as well as a dual part for dual extrusion as seen in the photos.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

50

Notes:

I printed everything in PLA at .15 with 50% infill. Supports were used on some parts. Using supports on the parts of the arm that slide into the body helps to make the arms stiffer when pulled out as the imperfections left from the supports create friction.
Clean up parts and press together. The model pictured is all press fit. A drop of glue where parts fit together would prevent any slippage as you change from one form to the other.
I used Fusion360 and a Flashforge Inventor with Inland PLA.

comments.text:
Very, very, very, did I say "very"? VERY! weak brackets on foot parts! Except this you have to own a very good calibrated printer, 'cause you will have a lot of afterprint work.
Conclusion: model is great, but VERY weak, not recommended for making.
comments.author: Arezus

comments.text: On my Flashforge Inventor, using Inland PLA, printed at .15 the only clean up of any kind I had to do was to pull the support off the arm swivel with my fingers. The foot brackets interlock into the hood section and when not glued I've had no trouble with them. Glued they feel very strong.
comments.author: Arezus

comments.text:
Don't understand me wrong, you have made a COLOSSAL work with this model, it's just awesome, but hinge is a really thin part, it asks to be more thick or with some kind of stiffener.
I will try to repeat my experience with it, but I printed 0.1 PLA and those hinges came off right after I gently tried to fit the detail.
Please tell me, you have printed the details in the position of STL files or you turned them flat? I turned them all to the position they will appear when in car mode, so nearly all the details turned 86 degrees. Maybe this caused thin and weak bridges. I can assume that I also have a scrappy 3d printer, but the edges are neat and all other connections are firm.

title: Ikea Gallant Filing Cabinet Plastic Drawer Clip

description.text:
Just as I was inserting my drawer into the just built cabinet, I though it got stuck and tried pulling it back out snapping the clip in half. This part comes pre-inserted in the drawer rail and so Ikea would need to replace the whole drawer under their warranty so I just figured I would Cad it and have it printed.

The model was printed with supports at 100 microns and worked first go round on PLA. Snapped right in place in the drawer rail and clicked in place when drawer was insterted. Works great. I found that only the filling cabinets have this piece as other drawers had a different mechanism.

If this ends up being useful to someone else then great, although doubtful considering most would just go with warranty replacement.

Este es mi robot DYOR creado para el curso "Diseña, fabrica y programa tu robot" de la Universidad Politécnica de Valencia.

Es una variante del famoso robot de la serie Futurama, Bender Doblador Rodríguez.

Proceso de diseño:

Antes de empezar a diseñar el robot DYOR con TinkerCAD, lo primero fue pensar en un diseño original del mismo.

Una de las cosas que más me llamó la atención del modelo fue la pantalla de LEDs que hace las veces de boca del robot. Al pensar en robots que conocía a los que pudiera adaptar ese componente rápidamente me vino a la cabeza el robot de la serie Futurama, Bender.

Además, el sensor de ultrasonidos también se adapta bastante bien a la forma de los ojos del robot así que he adaptado ligeramente su forma para que sea parecido al original.

Por otro lado, las manos que lleva el modelo son simplemente decorativas ya que con las piezas de Lego que irán conectadas a los servos podré hacer los verdaderos brazos extensores de Bender, al añadir o quitar más piezas de Lego.

El diseño de las piezas está pensado para que el cuerpo de Bender encaje en la base a través de la ranura que esta tiene. Si hubiera holguras, la idea es pegar una pieza a la otra con pegamento o silicona caliente.

Diseños TinkerCAD:

  • Bender DYOR: simplemente es un diseño para visualizar cómo sería el robot y dónde iría cada componente electrónico. Destacar que el zumbador está colocado detrás del cuerpo de Bender ya que el robot original no tiene nariz.

  • Base Bender: si el tamaño de la cama de la impresora no es suficientemente grande como para imprimir ambas piezas juntas, se puede utilizar este archivo para imprimir solo esta pieza (85 x 150).

  • Cuerpo Bender: exactamente lo mismo que en el caso anterior. Si el tamaño de la cama de la impresora no es suficientemente grande como para imprimir ambas piezas juntas, se puede utilizar este archivo para imprimir solo esta pieza (147 x 156).

  • Base y cuerpo juntos: si la impresora tiene una cama lo suficientemente grande como para imprimir ambas piezas juntas (258 x 156), se puede utilizar este archivo.

El tamaño extra del cuerpo de Bender se debe al diseño de la antena y los brazos pero no deberían suponer ningún problema a la hora de realizar el montaje y en el funcionamiento del robot.

Decoración del cuerpo del robot:

Para que sea más realista el diseño, he cubierto el cuerpo del robot con gomaEVA gris. Otra opción es realizar la impresión directamente en ese color.
Imágenes del proceso de decoración.

Componentes electrónicos y mecánicos

El diseño está pensado para que el robot contenga los siguientes componentes:

1 Placa Arduino Nano v3.0 + placa Expansion I/O para Arduino Nano
2 Servos SG90M para los brazos extensibles de Lego
2 Servos FS90R para ruedas de 60mm
1 Sensor de ultrasonidos SR-HC04
1 Módulo para seguir líneas TCRT5000
1 conector Bluetooth HC-06
1 zumbador pasivo KY-006
1 pantalla de Leds 8x8 (max 7219)
1 powerbank USB

Esquemas electrónica en Fritzing: Montaje de piezas y componentes mecánicos y electrónicos:

En construcción...

Pantalla de la App:

En la fila superior se encuentran los iconos de conexión y desconexión Bluetooth entre la App y el robot, el icono de activación de navegación, los iconos de estado de ánimo, el icono para activar el sensor de ultrasonidos y el icono para activar el siguelíneas.

En la segunda fila hay un piano en el que cada nota tiene un color y al presionar las teclas cada nota será reproducida por el robot.

En la tercera fila están los iconos de control del robot.

En la cuarta fila los iconos de ajuste de pinzas (izquierda y derecha) y control de pinzas (izquierda y derecha).

A mount to attach an LG G4 smartphone to my spotter scope eyepiece to make it easier to take photos.

My print is off a lil from the center of the bed. I did a quick dirty job to calibrate.
From the photo, you can see in my case the center is off 4 mm to the left and 8 mm to the top.

I drew the center line in the back of the glass before I printed this part. To fix this, I did the following commands in the terminal:
Shift the bed dimension to the right 4 mm and forward 8 mm
->> M206 X-4 Y8
save it to EEPROM with M500

Please prefer to your printer's configuration and coordinate to adjust the dimensions correctly using "negative" or "positive" number.

Source: http://reprap.org/wiki/Configuring_Marlin_Bed_Dimensions

title: Tevo Tarantula corner bracket and top mounted spool holder combo

description.text:
I had printed out Dintid's spool holder (found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1000323)

Finished end of spool rod with knob borrowed from galaxius' project here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:754248

STL's from those projects have been included here.

Decided I didn't like the spool jutting out front of the left leg per dintid's original setup, mainly due to the gap I needed to leave to allow clearance for the hotend and the 5015 fan mounted on top of it.

With that setup the spool ended up about 2-3 inches away from the leg which meant the filament would need to make an almost 90deg turn to feed the extruder motor mounted on top of the frame.

So I opted to mount the spool on top of the frame but I also wanted to reinforce the corner, so I designed this to fill both roles.

Hole and cutout in uprights are 8mm, I'm using a 5/16" rod and it was a tight fit, needed to bore it out with a slightly larger drill bit to allow rod to slip in and out freely.

Sloped the upper edge of hole inside the upright and lower edge on outside to make it easier to insert rod end on an angle without having to flex the arms to make room.

title: Banana Plug Cover / Insulator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a cover for a std. 4mm male banana plug. It slips over and completely covers the metal portion of the plug. The lower part is just over 4mm for a snug fit, while the top part is as wide as possible to allow for tapered plugs, etc.

I often have test leads connected at various points in a circuit and swap them in and out of my DMM or scope. With this, I can safely insulate the other end of the lead that's unplugged from my DMM/scope (but still connected to the circuit on the other end) to avoid shorting out the circuit or getting shocked.

The various leads I own have 4 different style of male banana plugs. I designed this to work with all of them. If you run into one that it doesn't work for, shoot me a pic and I'll see what I can do.

I printed these in PLA with 15% infill and a .40 nozzle. The upper most portion is only .80 wide. It's designed to get exactly two passes and bond well with a .40 nozzle.

Anet A8 (highly custom)

title: RAM-Compatible mount, Reinforced
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm dubious about the strength of FDM-printed models. Specifically layer adhesion vs. torque in narrow members. Most of my prints have presented no problems at all -- I have a 75mm Companion Cube printed in PLA that I like to beat against desks to the amazement of onlookers. But I've had several working parts fail in use due to layer delamination.

I love the idea of DIY RAM-compatible components. However, the real thing is made with metal, which is of course much more durable in this sort of application. So why not try adding a little metal to these DIY components?

Supports might be tricky here. They'll be needed in the recess for the screw head, but hopefully won't be needed anywhere else. I'm not sure how the M6 threads will turn out without it, but I'm sure cleaning the supports out of the threads would be a nightmare. I set the angle of the end of the screw hole to 85° so supports won't be necessary there. To sidestep the issue entirely, I've designed the 1/4" model with a recess for a 1/4-20 hex nut. It should be deep enough to use a Nylock nut with a 1/4-20 x 1.25" pan head machine screw. The two M6 models are designed for pan heads and socket heads. I've created an experimental M3 version, since I happen to have a load of M3 screws and nuts and washers, which uses an M3 reinforcement screw as well as adjusting all the mounting holes to takean M3 screw and washer.

I expect to further develop the concept. I'm curious to see how the base plate holds up (may want to explore a mending plate reinforcement), and whether or not the nut opening causes any problems with the arm grip. If the threads don't print well without support, I'll try a smooth-bore, and simply set the screw or some other sort of rod with epoxy.

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

You'll want very strong walls and infills so that the ball can stand up to the clamping forces of the RAM arms. I've been using 66% infill with 3-layer shells, and that has worked so far.

I've uploaded two more .STL files with "supported" in the name. These include supporting cylinders in the screw head cavity in case your slicer won't allow you to create custom supports.

print_settings.Notes:: Upper link mounts

description.text:
Here's several parts to enable you to fit a (in my case heavily dremeled) Tamiya Sand Scorcher body onto your HG P402 chassis. It was a big challenge for me to make everything fit neatly and make the steering and suspension function properly, but it looks very promising! Still a work in progress, so I can't wait to drive it properly!

If you use all the files here, you can convert your stock HG P402 chassis into a shorter, studier chassis, featuring a rear 4-link rear, 3-link + panhard front suspension and a larger steering angle!

Note that I moved all 4 shock hoops inwards. Mount the front end of the shock hoop into the rear hole (if that makes sense). Slightly bend the hoop down and drill a new hole in your chassis beam to mount the other end. I also cut off the front of the chassis beams where the servo mount ends. I will probably also cut up the rear end of the chassis beams, but more on that later..

The parts to print:

  • Servo Mount
  • C-hubs with 8 degrees of caster and a panhard mount. Mirror 1 of these accordingly.
  • Upper link mounts - let's get rid of those nasty Y-spaghettis
  • Battery mount
  • Body mounts

Everything bolts up with M3 (mostly M3x14) hardware I also used M3x8 (to connect the c-hubs to the axles, M3x16, M3x20. Because of my earlier experiences with PLA, i decided to design the holes to be very easily driled out to 2.5/2.6mm. You can then either tap a thread or just "force" your bolt in there (use quality hardware if you decide to do this).

I made all the suspension linkage of M4 threaded rod and Traxxas 5347 rod connectors. Adjuist the length to the tire size and body you're using. I finished the lower links and steering links off with some 4x6mm aluminium pipe. For the upper links and panhard link i cut up some 4mm shrink tube (no shrinking required) and forced it around the threads.

I had to use a 1.25" or 32mm servo horn to get the right linkage angle and steering throw.

To make the panhard bar fit, you'll have to bend and twist the link or it will either hit the axle or your chassis beam/servo mount. It takes a bit of fiddling, but it'll work in the end!

For this build I managed to get my hands on some Axial Icon 90mm oil shocks and fitted some softer lower springs i had randomly laying around.

This build took me a lot of figuring out and I may not have covered everything, so feel free to ask any questions!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.25 layers

Infill:

Suit yourself :)

Notes:

Body mounts
Front body mount is made to fit into the shock hoops instead of your body posts. The rear body mount fits on top of your body posts. I used velcro to mount the body to them. Print the rear mount with the tallest side facing down. You may need to use a 2-3mm brim for this part.

Servo Mount
I printed this "nose-down" with supports. Not sure if this is ideal, so do it differently as you please. It screws to the chassis using M3x14 bolts. Note that there is no mounting hole on the front left, to make room for the bolt that holds the panhard bar. Room for improvement here! I just drilled an extra 2.5mm hole through the chassis, into the part and jammed an m3x10 nut in. Not the most elegant way to do it, but it sits just fine.

Battery Mount
To make the battery fit between the body, it had to sit as close to the transmission as possible. I use a 2S 5800mAh hardcase lipo which leaves just a small gap between the spur and shifting linkage. I used velcro straps to clamp the battery tight on there (there is no other sideways fixation due to the narrow fit between the body). Make sure that your battery is centered! (or use a shorty lipo).

C-hubs
You will need to mirror one of these or your caster will be going the wrong way! I used supports inside the hubs which can be somewhat of a struggle to remove (don't make them too strong). I used M3x8mm bolts on the front and M3x14 bolts for the rear side/shock.

Upper link mounts
Print these flat-side down using a tiny support for the axle mount. Take your axle apart, take out he ball joint and screw them together. Make your printed mount fit into the newly enlarged hole. From the other side, thread in an M3x14 or M3x16 bolt. Make sure you use a 3mm flat washer behind the head or the bolt won't fixyour part properly onto the axle! Use M3x14 bolts to mount your upper links. On the chassis side of your link, use spacers (3mm washers, 2pcs each) between the pivot ball and the chassis beam.

comments.text:
NICE JOB!!! I'm not using all of them (that might change if I decide to do a Bug!!). I am using the Chubs and 4-Link Mounts. Those are SO clever!!
(BTW, as a Retired Auto Technician, I KNOW that the increased Caster will increase high speed stability AND increase side hilling performance!)

remixed_from.author: Insonia
remixed_from.title: Oculus CV1 prescription fixed-frame（15mm vertex distance）

title: Oculus CV1 prescription fixed-frame with Higher Bridge（15mm vertex distance）

description.text:
I printed Insonia's remix and it was better for my high prescription than Jegstad's original design but the Bridge was very uncomfortable for me, it was basically stabbing my nose. My solution was to raise the bridge a bit higher and cut an arch into it so that it went above my nose.

Higher_Bridge_43mm.stl is my second attempt at this, not necessarily better than my first attempt (Custom_Solid_Frame.stl), just done in a program that I found more easy to work with.

Custom_Solid_Frame.stl has a narrower more angled bridge. Not sure which design is better yet, probably comes down to each person's facial features.

EDIT 8/3/17: added Higher_Bridge_43mm_V2.stl, which has a less angular top for the Bridge, as before it was poking my eyebrows if i didn't sand it a bit.

8/10/17: Higher_Bridge_43mm_V3.stl has the inner part of the lense frame curved around the nose.

author: omair94

title: PCB Box with Snap Fit Hinge Lid

description.text:
This is a simple box to hold a custom PCB. This PCB uses optocouplers and an MCP23017 port-expander to monitor 24VAC output on 16 channels over i2c. The address is selectable and the board is designed to be daisy-chained with up to 7 other boards for up to 128 sensing channels.
Each board also has 4 individual channels that do not pass through the port expander but can be polled using any digital pin.

Check my hackaday page for more info.
https://hackaday.io/project/26202-16-channel-24vac-detection-over-i2c

The PCB size is:
93.5mm x 63mm x 13mm as pictured. Mount holes are 4mm and spaced 7.25mm/7.25mm x/y from the corners.

The box features snap fit hinges!
The hinges and their snap-fit is designed for Esun PLA+, but the fit can be changed with the variable claspCut = claspDiam/4.5. claspCut can be set between = claspDiam/2.5 to claspDiam/6 as needed.
The box can be scaled but claspCut should be changed as needed.

SCAD code is MESSY!

author: RAV174

description.text:
This is a skirt panel for the IKEA Lack tables.
Pieces are left, center and right. Each side is 200mm and the center is 185mm. Move it around how you like to print it.
Since the Lack tables are symmetric, this can mount between any two legs.
Customize it to add holes for switches, displays, whatever!

I added the top support brackets after I printed mine to prevent bowing.

edit: I added a right side panel for this display: http://www.gearbest.com/laser-rangefinder-electronic-distance-meter/pp_679381.html
They are all over eBay under 4-in-1 Volmeter for $7-$8
I will post pics after I print it.

Printed at 0.2mm with a .4 nozzle
20% infill is nice and sturdy

Holes should line up and are 4mm depending on your print quality.
I used M3 screws and they fit just right.
I printed vertically so supports are only needed for whatever holes were added.
It's probably a good idea to print with a >5mm brim to help avoid warping at the far corners.

If it seems to fit too tight or too loose, rotate the legs slightly and it will fit right in!

I designed this in TinkerCad. I am no expert and it works great for uncomplicated designs.

I added a cutout for the Volt/Ammeter, a hole for my LED switch and a hole for the IR detector for the LED strip lights
